title: CVE-2022-35260: .netrc parser out-of-bounds access

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!
I can reproduce. Will dig deeper can get back.

This is a read out-of-bounds read (and write) happens on stack. The 4096 bytes buffer is followed by `netrcbuffsize` on the stack, which is what will be partially read when read past the boundary. That is a an `int` with a value of decimal 4096 so 0x00001000  or 00100000 in hex depending on endianess, meaning that the following byte is always a zero. That read is wrong, but seems benign.

The out of bounds write is also done on the same address, meaning it will write a zero to that same address previously read from.

I might be wrong, but from where I look at it so far, this look like two totally benign errors that by a fluke actually do not cause any problems other than alarming valgrind and other tools with this input.

Am I wrong?

Sorry for the late reply.

The idea of using curl_get_line() looks good.
But I thought it doesn't meet the format of the .netrc file.

`Each field is provided as a sequence of letters that ends with a space or newline.`
https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/netrc

Lines ending in spaces cannot be read by Curl_get_line().

Sorry if I misunderstood the format of the .netrc file.

I don't think this is a benign error.
I've used [this](https://curl.se/windows/dl-7.85.0_5/curl-7.85.0_5-win64-mingw.zip) in a Windows environment to confirm an application crash.
I will post again because it will be long.
Please give me some time.

> Each field is provided as a sequence of letters that ends with a space or newline

Yes, but it doesn't say that it supports super long lines without newline. I think it is a fairly safe work-around.

> to confirm an application crash

Ah curious. Then my presumption was wrong...

I presume then that the compiler puts the array in a different spot on the stack so that reading beyond the end actually causes a crash.

Can you think of how this becomes a security problem and not just a crash?

> Yes, but it doesn't say that it supports super long lines without newline. I think it is a fairly safe work-around.
You're right. I think that it is a good modification and good specification change if existing users can accept it.

> \0 does not stop the loop on line 13 because the result of ISSPACE() is false.

Ah right,. as long as it is a non-space it will continue and a null-byte is not a space and neither is 0x10. It will read past those until it accidentally hits a space or reads illegal memory and crashes.

> Can you think of how this becomes a security problem and not just a crash?

If you have a server program that communicates using an externally passed .netrc file, I would say a denial of service due to an application crash.
I think that specifying CURLOPT_NETRC or CURLOPT_NETRC in curl_easy_setopt() will also cause a problem, so it is recognized that it will be a problem not only with the curl command but also with programs that use libcurl.

Agreed. I will write up a first security advisory draft for this issue within a day or two.

Since this issue is not set **high** nor **critical**, we would like to work on this issue, create a detailed security advisory, create a patch and ideally one or two tests and then **go public in sync with the pending next release** (this might then end up as one out of several issues that go public on the same date). We hope this is okay with you, as otherwise we can certainly discuss and maybe work out an expedited schedule.

Thank you for agreeing.
Understood.
It seems I introduced this flaw here: https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/eeaae10c0fb27aa06

I'm thinking CWE-121:

CWE-121: Stack-based Buffer Overflow

additional_data.old_title: Using a file without spaces or newlines as .netrc will result in an out-of-bounds read (& 1 byte out-of-bounds write).

activities.message: I'm attaching my initial take at a security advisory for this flaw.

> I'm thinking CWE-121:

It’s exactly as you said.

I'm sorry I didn't make it clear enough.
`Depending on memory conditions, even a single byte file can cause problems.`
I should have clarified this part

The file was 4095 bytes because it was prone to problems.

I believe this problem can occur even if the .netrc file contains only 1 byte.
fgets() does not do padding.
netrcbuffer is an uninitialized variable.
So the remaining 4094 bytes will be random values (depending on the compiler and optimization options).
In most cases, somewhere in the remaining 4094 bytes, ISSPACE() becomes true and the phenomenon ceases to occur. However, this is not 100% certain to be the case.

Ah right, 4095 bytes makes it more likely to read beyond the the buffer but to trigger the error you just need a trailing line of non-whitespace without a newline.

I'll update the description to say:

---
curl can be told to parse a `.netrc` file for credentials. If that file ends
in a line with consecutive non-white space letters and no newline, curl could
read past the end of the stack-based buffer, and if the read works, write a
zero byte possibly beyond its boundary.

That’s right.
thank you for the update.

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
